segment.source: xDeferLoadStrategy attribute
segment.target: xDeferLoadStrategy attribute

segment.source: xDeferLoadStrategy delays the creation of an element and its children, decreasing startup time but increasing memory usage slightly.
segment.target: xDeferLoadStrategy delays the creation of an element and its children, decreasing startup time but increasing memory usage slightly.

segment.source: Each element affected adds about 600 bytes to the memory usage.
segment.target: Each element affected adds about 600 bytes to the memory usage.

segment.source: x:DeferLoadStrategy attribute
segment.target: x:DeferLoadStrategy attribute

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: x:DeferLoadStrategy="Lazy" delays the creation of an element and its children, decreasing startup time but increasing memory usage slightly.
segment.target: x:DeferLoadStrategy="Lazy" delays the creation of an element and its children, decreasing startup time but increasing memory usage slightly.

segment.source: Each element affected adds about 600 bytes to the memory usage.
segment.target: Each element affected adds about 600 bytes to the memory usage.

segment.source: The larger the element tree you defer, the more startup time you'll save, but at the cost of a greater memory footprint.
segment.target: The larger the element tree you defer, the more startup time you'll save, but at the cost of a greater memory footprint.

segment.source: Therefore it's possible to overuse this attribute to the extent that your performance decreases.
segment.target: Therefore it's possible to overuse this attribute to the extent that your performance decreases.

segment.source: XAML attribute usage
segment.target: XAML attribute usage

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: The restrictions for using x:DeferLoadStrategy are:
segment.target: The restrictions for using x:DeferLoadStrategy are:

segment.source: Requires an x:Name defined, as there needs to be a way to find the element later.
segment.target: Requires an x:Name defined, as there needs to be a way to find the element later.

segment.source: Only a UIElement can be marked as deferred, with the exception of types deriving from FlyoutBase.
segment.target: Only a UIElement can be marked as deferred, with the exception of types deriving from FlyoutBase.

segment.source: Root elements can not be deferred in a Page, a UserControls, nor a DataTemplate.
segment.target: Root elements can not be deferred in a Page, a UserControls, nor a DataTemplate.

segment.source: Elements in a ResourceDictionary cannot be deferred.
segment.target: Elements in a ResourceDictionary cannot be deferred.

segment.source: Does not work with loose XAML loaded with XamlReader.Load.
segment.target: Does not work with loose XAML loaded with XamlReader.Load.

segment.source: Moving a parent element will clear out any elements that have not been realized.
segment.target: Moving a parent element will clear out any elements that have not been realized.

segment.source: There are several different ways to realize the deferred elements:
segment.target: There are several different ways to realize the deferred elements:

segment.source: Call FindName with the name that was defined on the element.
segment.target: Call FindName with the name that was defined on the element.

segment.source: Call GetTemplateChild with the name that was defined on the element.
segment.target: Call GetTemplateChild with the name that was defined on the element.

segment.source: In a VisualState, use a Setter or Storyboard animation that is targeting the deferred element.
segment.target: In a VisualState, use a Setter or Storyboard animation that is targeting the deferred element.

segment.source: Target the deferred element in any Storyboard.
segment.target: Target the deferred element in any Storyboard.

segment.source: Use a binding that is targeting the deferred element.
segment.target: Use a binding that is targeting the deferred element.

segment.source: NOTE: Once the instantiation of an element has started, it is created on the UI thread, so it could cause the UI to stutter if too much is created at once.
segment.target: NOTE: Once the instantiation of an element has started, it is created on the UI thread, so it could cause the UI to stutter if too much is created at once.

segment.source: Once a deferred element is created by any of the methods listed above, several things will happen:
segment.target: Once a deferred element is created by any of the methods listed above, several things will happen:

segment.source: The Loaded event on the element will get raised.
segment.target: The Loaded event on the element will get raised.

segment.source: Any bindings on the element will get evaluated.
segment.target: Any bindings on the element will get evaluated.

segment.source: If the application has registered to receive property change notifications on the property containing the deferred element(s), the notification will be raised.
segment.target: If the application has registered to receive property change notifications on the property containing the deferred element(s), the notification will be raised.

segment.source: You can nest deferred elements, however they have to be realized from the outer-most element in.
segment.target: You can nest deferred elements, however they have to be realized from the outer-most element in.

segment.source: If you try to realize a child element before the parent has been realized, an exception will be raised.
segment.target: If you try to realize a child element before the parent has been realized, an exception will be raised.

segment.source: In general, the recommendation is to defer things that are not viewable in the first frame.
segment.target: In general, the recommendation is to defer things that are not viewable in the first frame.

segment.source: A good guideline for finding candidates to be deferred is to look for elements that are being created with collapsed Visibility.
segment.target: A good guideline for finding candidates to be deferred is to look for elements that are being created with collapsed Visibility.

segment.source: Also incidental UI (that is, UI that is triggered by user interaction) is a good place to look for deferring elements.
segment.target: Also incidental UI (that is, UI that is triggered by user interaction) is a good place to look for deferring elements.

segment.source: Be wary of deferring elements in a ListView scenario, as it will decrease your startup time, but could also decrease your panning performance depending on what you're creating.
segment.target: Be wary of deferring elements in a ListView scenario, as it will decrease your startup time, but could also decrease your panning performance depending on what you're creating.

segment.source: If you are looking to increase panning performance, please refer to the {x:Bind} markup extension and x:Phase attribute documentation.
segment.target: If you are looking to increase panning performance, please refer to the {x:Bind} markup extension and x:Phase attribute documentation.

segment.source: If the x:Phase attribute is used in conjunction with x:DeferLoadStrategy then, when an element or an element tree is realized, the bindings will be applied up to and including the current phase.
segment.target: If the x:Phase attribute is used in conjunction with x:DeferLoadStrategy then, when an element or an element tree is realized, the bindings will be applied up to and including the current phase.

segment.source: The phase specified for x:Phase will not affect or control the deferral of the element.
segment.target: The phase specified for x:Phase will not affect or control the deferral of the element.

segment.source: When a list item is recycled as part of panning, realized elements will behave in the same way as other active elements, and compiled bindings ({x:Bind} bindings) will be processed using the same rules, including phasing.
segment.target: When a list item is recycled as part of panning, realized elements will behave in the same way as other active elements, and compiled bindings ({x:Bind} bindings) will be processed using the same rules, including phasing.

segment.source: A general guideline is to measure your application before and after to make sure you are getting the performance that you want.
segment.target: A general guideline is to measure your application before and after to make sure you are getting the performance that you want.

segment.source: Example
segment.target: Example
